__data__.text:
France's pension system, which is largely pay-as-you-go, has been a subject of reform discussions for many years due to budget shortfalls and an increasing number of pensioners. The system, which has ensured a guaranteed state-backed pension for retirees, has been strained by rising life expectancy and a decreasing worker-to-retiree ratio. France has one of the lowest retirement ages among industrialized nations and spends a significant portion of its GDP on pensions.

To keep the system financially viable, the French government, under President Macron, proposed pension reforms that would gradually raise the legal retirement age to 64 by 2030, increase the number of years required for a full pension, and eliminate special pension rules for certain sectors. These reforms aimed to balance the pensions deficit by 2030 and create a surplus to fund early retirement options for physically demanding jobs.

However, the proposed reforms faced opposition from various trade unions, which argued that the changes would disproportionately affect low-income workers in manual jobs and women, who typically retire later and with lower pensions. Polls showed that the majority of the population opposed the reforms and the use of Article 49.3 to enact them without a parliamentary vote.

In March 2023, President Macron invoked Article 49.3 to pass the pension reform bill, avoiding a vote in the National Assembly due to uncertainty about securing enough support. This decision was seen as a defeat and a sign of weakness for the government, causing a decline in Macron's approval ratings and sparking criticism about the perceived brutality and undemocratic nature of using Article 49.3. The reforms are expected to result in women retiring later and working longer hours, while disproportionately impacting blue-collar workers.

France's pension reforms, proposed by President Macron, have been met with widespread opposition and protests. The reforms aim to balance the pensions deficit by 2030 and create a surplus but are criticized for disproportionately affecting women and blue-collar workers. Women are expected to retire later and work longer hours, while manual laborers will be hit hardest by the changes. The use of Article 49.3 to pass the bill without a parliamentary vote has been seen as undemocratic and a sign of weakness for the government. Opponents argue that the reforms prioritize businesses and the wealthy, burdening blue-collar workers, and dispute the need for urgency. The unpopularity of the reforms is also attributed to Macron's pre-existing image as an out-of-touch "president of the rich." Protests have led to instances of violence and rioting, with over a million people taking to the streets nationwide. Union members have blocked fuel deliveries, aiming to bring the French economy to a halt. Despite this, Macron has emphasized that the pension reforms will go forward.

France has experienced widespread protests against President Macron's pension reforms, which aim to balance the pensions deficit by 2030 and create a surplus. The reforms have been criticized for disproportionately affecting women and blue-collar workers, who will have to retire later and work longer hours. The use of Article 49.3 to pass the bill without a parliamentary vote has been seen as undemocratic and a sign of weakness for the government.

In Paris, over 500,000 people demonstrated against the reform according to the CGT, while 93,000 demonstrated according to the prefecture. Union members blocked fuel deliveries, aiming to bring the French economy to a halt. Protests and strikes have caused disruptions in transportation and other sectors, with hundreds of thousands of people participating in demonstrations across the country.

After the announcement that the pension reforms would be enacted without a parliamentary vote, protests erupted and politicians from across the political spectrum denounced the move. Opposition MPs sang the national anthem in order to prevent the Prime Minister from speaking, forcing the session to be briefly suspended. Opposition leaders have called for no-confidence motions and accused the government of deploying a "permanent coup d'état" to shove through the legislation.

Following the use of Article 49.3, protests and clashes with police have occurred in Paris and other cities, resulting in numerous arrests and injuries. The CGT has announced further strikes and demonstrations for 23 March, describing the move by the government as "a complete denial of democracy".

Following the enactment of pension reforms without a parliamentary vote, widespread protests and strikes have occurred across France, with over half a million people demonstrating in Paris alone. The use of Article 49.3 to pass the bill has been criticized as undemocratic and has led to clashes between protesters and police, resulting in numerous arrests and injuries. Protests have caused disruptions in transportation and other sectors, with unions calling for further strikes and demonstrations. A multi-party no-confidence motion has been tabled in the National Assembly, and the Interior Minister has warned against violent protests and chaos. Despite protests being banned in certain areas, widespread protests have continued, with demonstrators calling for the resignation of President Macron. Other forms of protest include the blocking of fuel deliveries, refineries, and roads, as well as the disruption of the Boulevard Périphérique and national train operator SNCF. Additionally, students have protested near Sorbonne University and the Institute of Political studies, and unions have urged workers to continue striking. The protests have led to the ransacking of a political office and the burning of effigies and public buildings, with police utilizing tear gas and water cannons to disperse protesters. Overall, the protests have caused significant disruptions and have led to calls for the resignation of President Macron and his government.

Following the passage of pension reforms without parliamentary consent, widespread protests and strikes have occurred across France, led by various unions and students. The use of Article 49.3 to pass the bill has been criticized as undemocratic, resulting in clashes, numerous arrests, and injuries. Protests have disrupted transportation and other sectors, with demonstrators demanding the resignation of President Macron. Despite bans, protests continue, leading to the ransacking of political offices, burning of effigies, and public building damage. Police have utilized tear gas and water cannons, while protesters have blocked fuel deliveries, refineries, and roads. The government may order striking workers to return to avoid fuel shortages. No-confidence motions have been tabled, but are not expected to pass due to the Republicans' refusal to support them. Airports, trains, and public services face disruptions, with teachers' unions calling for strikes during baccalauréat exams. Fuel shortages are reported in major cities, with up to 8% of petrol stations affected nationwide. Spontaneous protests have erupted in Paris, with protesters chanting for Macron's resignation.

Following the passage of contentious pension reforms in France, widespread protests and strikes have led to fuel shortages, transportation disruptions, and property damage. The use of Article 49.3 to pass the bill has been criticized as undemocratic. Fuel shortages have affected 7% of petrol stations nationwide, with some cities experiencing more severe shortages. Protesters have called for the resignation of President Macron, and no-confidence motions have been tabled but are not expected to pass. The government may order striking workers to return to avoid further fuel shortages. Police have utilized tear gas and water cannons, while protesters have blocked fuel deliveries and refineries. Spontaneous protests have erupted in Paris and other cities, resulting in arrests and property damage. The government has announced that it will submit the new law to France's Constitutional Council for review, and Prime Minister Borne has expressed solidarity with injured police officers. Macron has stated that he does not intend to withdraw the reforms or call for new elections.

Following the passage of contentious pension reforms in France, widespread protests and strikes have led to fuel shortages, transportation disruptions, and property damage. The use of Article 49.3 to pass the bill has been criticized as undemocratic. In Paris, police have ordered rubbish collectors back to work, but protests and blockades, such as at a blockaded incineration plant in Ivry-sur-Seine, continue. Protesters have blocked fuel deliveries and refineries, resulting in fuel shortages affecting 13% of petrol stations and almost half the pumps in the Bouches-du-Rhône area. Unions have announced another day of strikes and demonstrations for 23 March, with significant disruptions expected in public transport and services. Demonstrations have turned violent in Paris, with riot police using tear gas and baton charges to disperse protesters. The government has mandated minimum staffing at all depots and submitted the new law to France's Constitutional Council for review.

The protests in France against the pension reforms continue to be contentious, with demonstrations and blockades occurring across the country. In Paris, the main demonstration route was filled with 800,000 protesters, leading to clashes with police and the use of tear gas. Violence was reported in other cities as well, with protesters blocking train tracks, storming government buildings, and setting fires. The government has condemned the attacks on police and government buildings, and over 80 people have been arrested nationwide. Union leaders have called for non-violence, but the protests are seen as a rejection of Macron's pension bill. The Constitutional Council has declared the pension bill to be compatible with the Constitution, and Macron has signed it into law. However, labor unions have rejected Macron's invitation to meet and have called for mass protests on May 1. Macron has acknowledged the anger over the pension reform and has vowed to address the issue in the next 100 days. Despite this, protesters continue to gather and jeer during Macron's tour of France, with some threatening to cancel the upcoming 2024 Summer Olympics if the pension reform is not withdrawn.

On April 14, the Constitutional Council approved the pension bill, and Macron signed it into law. Labor unions rejected Macron's invitation for a meeting, calling for mass protests on May 1. On May 1, protests occurred across France, resulting in injuries to 108 police officers, 291 arrests, and property damage. Union leaders announced another nationwide protest on June 6. Concerns have been raised about increasing violence in the protests, with some comparing them to the Yellow Vests protests. Union leaders have expressed concerns about the growing radicalization and violence, while Macron and the government have been criticized for not addressing the anger and dissent. The protests have not been huge in terms of scale but have been led by committed left-wing activists. The waste collection strike has also contributed to the ongoing unrest. The government has been urged to address the anger and dissent to prevent further escalation of violence.

The leaders of moderate unions, Cyril Chabanier of CFTC and Laurent Berger of CFDT, have expressed concerns about the growing radicalization and violence in the ongoing protests against the pension reforms in France. Berger warned that if protesters feel that violence is more effective than peaceful demonstrations, the protests could become more violent. This comes as some members of the Republicans and Renaissance parties have received threatening emails and the waste collection strike in Paris, which began on March 6, has resulted in the accumulation of 10,000 tonnes of uncollected rubbish on the streets. The proposed pension reforms would raise the retirement age of Paris' municipal waste collectors from 57 to 59. The strike was suspended on March 29 due to declining participation. There have been concerns over the use of arbitrary police custody and mass arrests, with some critics accusing the government of using criminal law to discourage demonstrations. The protests have been compared to the gilet jaunes movement and there are concerns that the invoking of Article 49.3 could erode support for the government and democratic institutions.

The leaders of moderate unions in France have expressed concerns about the growing radicalization and violence during the ongoing protests against pension reforms. The protests have been marked by the use of excessive force by police, resulting in injuries to both officers and protesters. The invocation of Article 49.3 to pass the reforms has been criticized for potentially eroding support for the government and democratic institutions. In response to the protests, some have suggested alternatives such as firing the Prime Minister, holding a referendum, or triggering a shared-initiative referendum (RIP). The proposed RIP would require the support of one-fifth of both the National Assembly and Senate, as well as the signatures of a tenth of the electorate. The state visit of King Charles III, initially scheduled for March 26-29, was postponed due to the ongoing protests. International reactions to the protests have been critical of the French government's handling of the situation, with human rights organizations and the United Nations expressing concern over the use of excessive force and arbitrary arrests.
